A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: Trial of the Flood-Flanagan Case Set for nay 6th. It was a case of rain outside and Flood inside yesterday, and a gen eral all-round April-fool for those who attended the Police Court in expectation that a result would be reached in the cause of Senator H. D. Flood, who is charged with an assault upon Senator W. M. Flana gan, of Powhatan. The difficulty between the sena tors occurred during the closing days of the legislative session, and the trial was set for to-day from an examination held early m the past month. At an early hour yesterday morn ing, men began to arrive, and at 10 oclock the court-room was crowded to its utmost capacity, for all thought that the much-discussed case would be finally determined. It was a little after 10 oclock when Justice Crutchfield called the case of H. D. Flood,and immediately the hum and buzz of the expectant throng caused Sergeant Thomas to rap vigorously for order. In the row of seats reserved for the attorneys sat Commonwealths- Attorney Harry Smith, and neur him sat Senator Flanagan, who was not represented by any assistant in the prosecution. General Edgar Allan, who was in the court in the former hearing was not present, and Judge Waddill, another friend of Mr. Flanagan was also absent. Senator Flood occupied a chair between Senator Conway R. Sands and Mr. Charles V. Meredith his counsel. Justice Crutchfield called the following witnesses Malcolm A. Coles, H. L. Maynard, 6. T. Snead, F. B. Watkins, Dr. Pierce, Dr. Jeffries, Dr. Michaux, O. T. Crump, James R. Werth, Morris Parr, Mor ris Evws, Major Robert Stiles, Frank Perkins, and Norman Ran dolph. He then announced that a number of the witnesses had not responded to their names, and the list was recalled. MR. EVANS ABSENT. Mr. Flanagan had then come in side the rail just before the Justice. He stated that Mr. Morris Evans, was not present. Mr. Smith asked Mr. Flanagan if he thought they could get along without Mr. Evans, and Mr. Flana gan replied that he considered Mr. Evans one of the most important of all the witnesses. It then became apparent that the case would have again to be post poned. Mr. Evans lives in Powha tan and was expected on the Alle ghany road from Columbia this morning. Justice Crutchfield had the railroad office telephoned to and found that the train had ar rive on time. It was then suggested that possibly Mr. Evans had been unable to reach the railroad on ac count of the high water in the river near Columbia. Justice Crutchfield announced that he was very sorry to be com pelled to again continue the case, as the witnesses were many of them, brought from some distance, and that the expense to the state was large. Mr. Smith here jocularly remarked that as many of the witnesses were members of the Legislature, they were also of course opposed to in creasing the criminal expenses of the State.
